content.html:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Functions \(a, b, c, d, e\), and \(f\) are given below. Which functions are linear? Select the three answers that apply.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.14.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(a(x)=3x\), \(d(x)=9+3x\), \( f(x)=9 \cdot 3x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Functions \(a, b, c, d, e\), and \(f\) are given below. Which functions are exponential? Select the two answers that apply.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.14.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(b(x)=3^x\), \(e(x)=9 \cdot 3^x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Here are 4 equations defining 4 different functions, \(a, b, c\), and \(d\). List them in order of increasing rate of change. That is, start with the one that grows the slowest and end with the one that grows the quickest.
    • \(a(x)=5x+3\)
    • \(b(x)=3x+5\)
    • \(c(x)=x+4\)
    • \(d(x)=1+4x\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(c(x)\), \(b(x)\), \(d(x)\), \(a(x)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the given information for problems 4–6. Technology is required. Function \(f\) is defined by \(f(x)=3x+5\), and function \(g\) is defined by \(g(x)=(1.1)^x\).

\(x\)

\(f(x)\)

 \(g(x)\)

1

5

10

20
  1. Which values will complete the table for \(f(x)\)?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.14.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 8, 20, 35, 65. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which of the following sets of values will complete the table for \(g(x)\)? \(g(x)=(1.1)^x\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.14.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1.1, 1.6, 2.59, 6.73. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. ________ is a linear function.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.14.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(f(x)\) is a linear function. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. ________ is an exponential function.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.14.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(g(x)\) is an exponential function. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Functions \(m\) and \(n\) are given by \(m(x)=(1.05)^x\) and \(n(x)=\frac{5}{8}x\). As \(x\) increases from 0, __________ reaches 30 first.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(n(x)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Functions \(m\) and \(n\) are given by \(m(x)=(1.05)^x\) and \(n(x)=\frac{5}{8}x\). As \(x\) increases from 0, __________ reaches 100 first.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.14.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(m(x)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The functions \(f\) and \(g\) are defined by \(f(x)=8x+33\) and \(g(x)=2 \cdot(1.2)^x\). Which function eventually grows faster, \(f\) or \(g\)? Explain how you know.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.14.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(g(x)\) grows faster because it is an exponential function. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A line segment of length \(l\) is scaled by a factor of 1.5 to produce a segment with length \(m\). The new segment is then scaled by a factor of 1.5 to give a segment of length \(n\).

    What scale factor takes the segment of length \(l\) to the segment of length \(n\)? 

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.14.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 2.25. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
